title: 1. Thesis
stimulusHtml:
1 point

Has acceptable thesis.

  • The thesis must explicitly state at least one similarity or one difference in land reforms resulting from both the Mexican and Russian Revolutions as evidenced in the documents.

  • The thesis must be explicitly stated in the introduction or conclusion of the essay.

  • The thesis may appear as one sentence or as multiple sentences.

  • A thesis that is split among multiple paragraphs is unacceptable.

  • A thesis that merely restates the prompt is unacceptable.

  • The thesis CANNOT count as meaning, evidence, or grouping.

title: 2. Document Interpretation
stimulusHtml:
1 point

Understands the basic meaning of documents. (May misinterpret one)

  • Students must address all ten of the documents.

  • Student must demonstrate understanding of the basic meaning of at least nine documents.

  • Context can demonstrate understanding.

    • Explicit, correct grouping does demonstrate understanding.

    • Merely restating verbatim or quoting the content of the documents does not demonstrate understanding

title: 3. Document Evidence
stimulusHtml:
2 points
Supports thesis with appropriate evidence from all or all but one document.

For 2 points:

  • Specific and accurate evidence comparing land reforms must be explicitly drawn from a minimum of nine documents.

  • Evidence must be used to demonstrate at least one direct similarity and one difference between the land reforms.

  • A document that is simply listed does not count as using the document as evidence.

For 1 point:

  • Specific and accurate evidence comparing land reforms must be explicitly drawn from a minimum of eight documents.

  • Evidence may demonstrate a similarity or a difference between the land reforms.

  • A document that is simply listed does not count as using the document as evidence.

title: 4. Point of View Analysis
stimulusHtml:
1 point
Analyzes point of view in at least two documents.

  • Students must correctly analyze point of view in at least two documents.

  • Point of view explains why this particular person might have this particular opinion or what particular feature informs the author’s point of view or tone.

  • Students must move beyond mere description by explaining how the characteristics of the author, the intended audience, and/or the intended outcome may have influenced the author’s opinion.

  • Students may challenge the veracity of the author’s point of view, but must move beyond a mere statement that the author is ‘biased’ by providing some plausible analysis.

  • Mere attribution is not sufficient. Attribution is copying or repeating information verbatim from the source line of the document.

title: 5. Document Analysis
stimulusHtml:
1 Point
Analyzes documents by grouping them in two ways.

  • Groupings must address with coherence a direct comparison between the land reforms in both Mexico and Russia. Examples of such groupings might include:

    • Similarities: goal of redistribution from wealthy to poor, peasant productivity, etc.

    • Differences: attitudes toward reform, level of coercion, success in land reform, etc.

  • Students must explicitly and correctly group the documents in at least two ways.

  • A minimum of two documents (used appropriately) constitutes a group or subgroup.

  • Students may not receive credit for both the larger group and the subgroups within it.

title: 6. Additional Documents
stimulusHtml:
1 point
Identifies and explains the need for one type of appropriate additional document or source.

Students must identify an appropriate additional document, source, or voice and explain how the document or source will contribute to analysis or comparison of land reforms.

title: Extended Core
stimulusHtml:
0-2 points
Expands beyond basic core of 1-7 points. A student must earn 7 points in the basic core area before earning points in the expanded core area.

Examples:

  • Provides more than one similarity and difference.

  • Has a clear, analytical, and comprehensive thesis

    • Goes well beyond the minimally acceptable thesis.

  • Shows careful and insightful analysis of the documents

    • Recognition of the historical context of the documents.

    • Analyzes all ten documents.

    • Explains corroboration and links between documents.

  • Uses documents persuasively as evidence

  • Analyzes point of view in most or all documents

    • Thoughtful analysis of author’s background, intended audience, tone, or historical context.

  • Inclusion of groupings beyond the two required.

  • Brings in accurate “outside” historical content.

  • Explains why additional types of document(s) or sources are needed

    • Identifies more than one type of appropriate additional document.

    • Provides a sophisticated explanation of why the additional document is necessary.

    • Request for additional document is woven into the essay and integrated into a broader analysis.
